channel.title: Education on It's Pronounced Metrosexual
channel.description: Recent content in Education on It's Pronounced Metrosexual

item.title: Social Justice Minus Dogma Online Course
item.description: Over the course of 6 weeks of self-guided learning (or however long you choose), explore the social justice dogma, identify its cornerstones and pitfalls, and plot a path forward toward true living social justice. This course is an extension of all the writing I've done here about “social justice dogma.

item.title: Introducing the Social Justice Compass
item.description:
Are you sailing the seas of social injustice, looking for a path toward equity, and in need of a tool that can point you in the right direction? Perhaps you are rethinking how you do social justice now, today, in 2019 ‚Äî with everything happening in the world ‚Äî and searching for a new path forward.

Avast! A new model for thinking about and doing social justice‚Ä¶ ho! This is off to a bad start. It turns out that every day can be International Talk like a Pirate Day if you don‚Äôt care about having friends.

But if you care about social justice, friend, well, look no further!

Today, I‚Äôm happy to share with you a new model for thinking about social justice, for considering your actions, attitudes, and beliefs, and for guiding yourself and your community toward equity: The Social Justice Compass.

Let‚Äôs dive right in.

item.title: If You‚Äôre Still Doing Social Justice How You Were Then, Reconsider.
item.description:
I‚Äôve seen people at conferences giving the same talk they gave two years ago. Activists speaking and organizing in ways unchanged since 2015. Educators facilitating workshops with a curriculum written in 2012.

The world is different now than it was then.

The people you‚Äôre working with ‚Äî or against, or for ‚Äî have different mindsets, beliefs, knowledge, perspectives, values, opinions, grudges, predispositions, awarenesses, and biases now than they did then.

The world you‚Äôre working in ‚Äî and trying to improve ‚Äî is comprised of different technologies, constituencies, zeitgeists, cultural norms, and public knowledge now than it was then.

And the ‚Äúthen‚Äù could be yesterday. Or last year. Your ‚Äúthen‚Äù could be ‚Äúbefore Trump was elected. Or ‚Äúwhen we didn‚Äôt know this huge thing.‚Äù Or ‚Äúbefore ‚ÄòBlack Lives Matter‚Äô activism started.‚Äù Or ‚Äúwhen we weren‚Äôt sure whether this one thing would work or not.‚Äù Or ‚Äúbefore our community experienced that travesty.‚Äù Or ‚Äúwhen we didn‚Äôt have social media.‚Äù

When I started doing social justice work, most people didn‚Äôt know what ‚Äúsocial justice‚Äù meant. They‚Äôd never heard the phrase. It was brand new to them. That was the first bar to jump: explaining what I was working to do.

That‚Äôs a ‚Äúthen‚Äù: when most people I encountered hadn‚Äôt heard the phrase ‚Äúsocial justice.‚Äù

item.title: The Genderbread Person version 4
item.description: A few hundred workshops, three years, and one book edition later, I‚Äôm happy to finally publish here my 4th version of the Genderbread Person. Check it out, download it, and share it with your educator friend who is still using v3.

item.title: Self-Guided Foundational Safe Zone Training
item.description: “Learn about your first impressions of LGBTQ+ people, core vocabulary, gender & sexuality theory, privilege & coming out, and get your questions answered.” That's from the course description, and does a good job of summing this up. I co-created this course with Meg Bolger based on our years of experience facilitating countless in-person Safe Zone workshops.

item.title: 3-Dimensional Social Justice
item.description: Despite a tidal wave of awareness of social justice issues (or maybe because of it), a lot of conversations are getting stuck. Some people are becoming increasingly ‚Äúanti social justice.‚Äù And we seem to be circling loops that go back decades.

item.title: A Few Pronoun Best [Preferred?] Practices
item.description: Pronouns: reentering prominence in many people‚Äôs lives for the first time since grammar school. How do we do them best? What should we avoid? A couple things to keep in mind up front: Pronouns replace people‚Äôs names (e.g., ‚ÄúSam is nice‚Äù ?

item.title: The Magical Power of ‚ÄúSome‚Äù for Social Justice Educators
item.description: There are few things that changed how effective of a social justice educator I was as much as the word ‚Äúsome.‚Äù It started as a way to correct people, or redirect them, or respond to problematic questions. Someone would ask something like ‚ÄúWhen people say they‚Äôre bisexual, isn‚Äôt it really just a phase?

item.title: Some Different Taxonomies for Social Justice People
item.description: We often group social justice people by identity, cause, or ‚Äú-ism‚Äù (e.g., racial justice people, gender justice, queer justice, wage justice). People outside of the social justice movement seem inclined to group SJ people as being either ‚Äúsocial justice warriors‚Äù or not.

item.title: One Huge Prickly Reason Why Anti-LGBTQ Folks Don‚Äôt Change Their Views
item.description: I need you to take a leap with me. Leap into the shoes of someone who has walked through their life knowing that being gay, being bi, lesbian, or pan, or that being non-binary, gender non-conforming, or trans ‚Äî that being different, different from straight, different from cisgender ‚Äî is wrong.

item.title: What's the best way to view gender? As a Spectrum? Continuums?
item.description: I was invited to give a Nerd Nite talk and speak about the subject I nerd out about the most: gender. And I got to talk about a lot of the dimensions of my work that I usually don't – stuff that usually stays behind the scenes.

item.title: What makes a relationship healthy? Unhealthy? These four things, to start.
item.description: It‚Äôs hard to define what a healthy relationship looks like because we all navigate relationships differently. Relationships are generally seen¬†through the lenses of our gender as well as our sexuality, but there are many other aspects of our identity that are going to inform what we¬†see as good or bad, desirable or detestable, healthy or unhealthy.

item.title: The Many Elements of Comprehensive Sexuality: Meet the Sexualitree
item.description: Sexuality is a touchy subject. For example, just that opening joke might have been enough to turn someone off (I could go all day.¬†But I won‚Äôt.). As easy as it is to make awkward puns, or be uncomfortable in general talking about sexuality, it‚Äôs¬†an important subject that affects all of us on different levels of our lives.

item.title: When Someone Comes Out To You: DO & DON‚ÄôT
item.description: In one of the first safe zone trainings I remember participating in, there was a loaded question about coming out¬†that was¬†followed by an excellent answer from the facilitator. The question was something like ‚ÄúWhy don‚Äôt some people come out of the closet?

item.title: Unlocking the Magic of Facilitation
item.description: “Meg and Sam have given us a gift; their book is smartly designed to invite new and seasoned facilitators to be intentional about having those tough group discussions. As an educator and facilitator, this book gives me a framework to understand my own facilitation style, and ways that I can continue to improve.

item.title: The Genderbread Person version 3
item.description: Taking the lessons learned from version 2, and applying them to sexuality in a more meaningful way, here‚Äôs my best rendition¬†of¬†the genderbread person yet. üíåMost Wednesdays I publish new Social Justice, Gender, & Sexuality Resources. Get the Email. Someone pointed out that I hadn‚Äôt shared this here yet, even though it‚Äôs been _out¬†_for awhile.

item.title: Empathy leads to Understanding
item.description: The other day I was at Lehigh University engaging in a bunch of conversations about identity, sexuality, gender, and social justice (ya know ‚Äî my jam). The groups I was talking with and to were eager and willing to learn, which is not to be taken for granted, but a sentiment kept popping up:¬†‚ÄúThis identity stuff is complicated.

item.title: The Intentions vs. Outcomes Matrix
item.description: It‚Äôs no secret I‚Äôm not a big fan of how highly we regard intentions. There‚Äôs even a whole chapter in my bookabout it, and it recently led to a great conversation, which led to this more visual representation of the dynamics between intentions and outcomes.

item.title: 15+ Fantastic Resources for Talking about ‚ÄúHomosexuality‚Äù (i.e., LGBTQ people) and The Bible
item.description: Only a tiny, tiny part of the bible can even be argued to reference ‚Äúhomosexuality‚Äù (and that argument, in a few of the verses in particular, is worth looking into), yet it seems like whenever we hear about the Bible in the news it‚Äôs being slammed against LGBTQ equality.

item.title: 9+ Silly Gender Comics I drew in 5 Minutes or Less
item.description: I made all of these comics for my book. Some of them are in there. Some didn‚Äôt make the cut. And many more that aren‚Äôt here did. Hope they give you a gender-equity giggle.

item.title: My TED Talk: Understanding the Complexities of Gender
item.description: I had the honor of being asked to give another TEDx talk, and they let me do it all about gender. You can watch the video below, and see as I try to condense hundreds of pages of my book into 16 minutes of comprehensible, enjoyable, and sometimes-rhyming words.

item.title: Comprehensive* List of LGBTQ+ Vocabulary Definitions
item.description: *This list is neither comprehensive nor inviolable, but it‚Äôs a work in progress toward those goals. With identity terms, trust the person who is using the term and their definition of it above any dictionary. These definitions are the creation of a cultural commons: emails, online discussions, and in-person chats, with the initial curation being mine, then growing into a collaboration between Meg Bolger and me at¬†TheSafeZoneProject.

item.title: You Soup: understanding diversity and the intersections of identity
item.description:
In doing the work I do, I often find myself struggling to help people make sense of the two extremes of identity: on one side we have the idea that people in a group are all the same (stereotypes); while the other side supports this idea that everyone is absolutely unique (snowflakes).

I find myself saying ‚Äúwe‚Äôre not the same, but we‚Äôre also not that different,‚Äù to the furrowing of brows, so I wanted to take a moment here to talk about the relationship of individual identity and social group memberships, as well as introduce a new graphic concept.

item.title: How to explain that bisexuality (or pansexuality) is real
item.description:
Bisexuality is a thing. It‚Äôs not just ‚Äúa stop between gay and straight.‚Äù But how do you explain that to someone who just. simply. won‚Äôt. believe. you.

I am going to focus on the struggle many bisexual and pansexual folks have convincing their straight (or gay/lesbian) peers that bisexuality¬†is an identity, not just a stopping point between two others. ¬†While I‚Äôm focusing this article on advice for bi- and pansexual folks, some of it applies to all sexuality discussions.

I have three main approaches you can take below, but I‚Äôd love to hear suggestions for more ways to breach this subject in the comments below.

item.title: Top Ten Tips on how to Thicken your Skin
item.description:
I received the following email from a high school senior (we‚Äôll call her Angie), replied to her, she appreciated the response and told me she‚Äôd be cool with me sharing it with you folks in case any one else might be able to find it useful.

Angie‚Äôs Email:

I need tips on how to thicken my skin.

Here‚Äôs my issue. I‚Äôm taking Gender/Sexuality Diversity in Literature (basically Gender Studies), and there are kids in my class who don‚Äôt believe in bisexuality, let alone *my* sexuality (aka. pansexuality). I‚Äôm an easy crier and I just know that when this rather basic problem surfaces‚Äìbecause I‚Äôve only ever heard these kids mutter their opinions under their breath‚ÄìI won‚Äôt make it through the conversation. So, tips?

I‚Äôve thought about coming out to the class (I‚Äôm out to my friends, family, most teachers, and Facebook, but most people don‚Äôt know) but haven‚Äôt. I want people to step on eggshells because they‚Äôre being inclusive, not because I‚Äôm in the room and they don‚Äôt want to offend me personally.

Any thoughts? Totally fine if not. A snarky one-liner would be just as welcome, because you‚Äôre hilarious and shit.

item.title: How To Avoid Being a Stereotype
item.description:
You want to be seen as an individual, right? ¬†Of course you do. ¬†But it‚Äôs bordering on impossible to avoid perpetuating at least some of the stereotypes attached to the various aspects of your identity. ¬†There are just too many of them!

Well, that‚Äôs where I can help. ¬†Consider this a ‚ÄúHow to be [X], without being a stereotypical [X]‚Äù guide. ¬†I‚Äôm hitting a variety of major identities, but feel free to request addendums to the guide in the comments below, on Facebook, or on Twitter.

Also, if you‚Äôre more prone to spot-reading than reading-reading, I strongly encourage you to at least read the last section before you formulate your reaction to this article.

Without further ado, in alphabetical order‚Ä¶

item.title: How to respond when someone uses non-inclusive (or bigoted) language
item.description:
Intentions don‚Äôt matter, outcomes do. ¬†However, I still think we need to do a much better job of being supportive of newcomers to the social justice ‚Äúscene‚Äù who may be well-intended, but don‚Äôt quite know the ropes yet. ¬†

Following is my picture guide (sorry, no flowchart) of how to properly handle such situations, without scaring off a potential ally.

item.title: The Costs of Marriage Inequality (an infographic)
item.description: This isn‚Äôt an IPM Edugraphic, but I felt compelled to get the message out. Check it out, be shocked, then head to takepart.com and do something about it. Annnnd go.

item.title: What does the asterisk in ‚Äútrans*‚Äù stand for?
item.description: A few people have asked why I write ‚Äútrans*‚Äù (with the asterisk) instead of just ‚Äútrans‚Äù when referring to trans* folks on my site. Well, I‚Äôm happy to answer that! üíåMost Wednesdays I publish new Social Justice, Gender, & Sexuality Resources.

item.title: 4 Reasons You Should Stop Saying ‚ÄúNon-Straight‚Äù
item.description: With all the talk of marriage equality, gay comic book weddings, and even gayer flowchartsflowing around the web, people are getting ever more sensitive about using inclusive language when they can. That‚Äôs great!¬†But more often than ever I am hearing folks use the term ‚Äúnon-straight‚Äù to refer to people who are lesbian, gay, bi-, pan- or even trans*.

item.title: 30+ Examples of Christian Privileges
item.description: Following is a list of privileges granted to people in the U.S. (and many western nations) for being Christian. üíåMost Wednesdays I publish new Social Justice, Gender, & Sexuality Resources. Get the Email. Please comment below if you have any additions or revisions to make!

item.title: 5 Reasons My Approach to Social Justice Work is Better than Yours
item.description:
The way I approach social justice and ally work on this site and¬†in my show has a distinct flavor. ¬†Some would call it sweet, but I think ginger is a bit spicy.

I don‚Äôt often do things by accident, and in this case it is very _on purpose. ¬†_My flavor is even so noticeable that if you‚Äôve seen a lot of what I‚Äôve created here, you‚Äôre likely taken aback by the headline of this article. ¬†Well, that actually leads me into my first point.

item.title: Why your intentions don‚Äôt really matter, but outcomes do
item.description:
I‚Äôve created a few¬†graphics¬†about when it‚Äôs okay to say ‚Äúgay‚Äù¬†and the one argument that keeps coming up goes something like ‚ÄúHow can you regulate language? What‚Äôs offensive to one person is not to another. ¬†What matters is your intentions.‚Äù

Intentions don‚Äôt matter, effect does.

I will elaborate on my response to that question more in a bit, but first I want to pose another question, and posit an answer.

item.title: Flowchart: I Want To Say Gay (When it‚Äôs Okay)
item.description: When I published my original flowchart, I said it was for the more analytical folks who are wondering if ‚Äúgay‚Äù is the right word choice for them. Well, this one is for the most¬†analytical folks, and also folks who enjoy data presented in cute and adorable ways.

item.title: Flowchart: when it‚Äôs okay to say ‚Äúthat‚Äôs so gay‚Äù
item.description: For the more analytical folks, we created a handy flowchart to help make the decision ‚ÄúIs ‚Äògay‚Äô the right word for me?‚Äù As you can tell, in most cases, the answer is no. Print, post, and share freely.

item.title: The Genderbread Person version 2
item.description: Hundreds of comments, ditto emails, ditto Facebook messages and Twitter tweeters and in-person holla-atchas and I feel like I‚Äôm finally in a place to release this. I give you the new and improved Genderbread Person! (click for larger size) Depending on what you folks have to say after checking this out and reading the rationale below, I‚Äôll be updating the Breaking through the Binary article and uploading a printer-friendly version of the new graphic.

item.title: When to use the word ‚Äúgay‚Äù
item.description: When is it “okay” to say gay? Why is this even a question we need to be asking? Well, because it seems that people have some misconceptions, and this flowchart makes it simple. This graphic was originally created to support this article, but then a comment was made saying this should be hung on every dorm wall in America.

item.title: The Genderbread Person
item.description: The Genderbread Person is an infographic that breaks down gender identity, gender expression, biological sex, and sexual orientation into an easy to understand visual. It‚Äôs been around in some form for many years, and this is my whack at making an inclusive, adorable, easy to understand depiction.

item.title: Political Correctness VS. Inclusiveness
item.description: I would never ask you to be politically correct. I‚Äôve gotten some flak from my ‚ÄúWhen Gay is Okay‚Äù and ‚ÄúWhy I say partner‚Äù articles. People feel that I‚Äôm soap-boxing for political correctness, when that couldn‚Äôt be further from the truth.

item.title: The Corruption of the Golden Rule
item.description: Do unto others as you would have them do unto you. Right? Wrong. What we‚Äôve been teaching our children, what I have learned and re-learned all of my life, is one of the worst pieces of advice around. What‚Äôs worse: it‚Äôs nearly universally accepted as gospel (pun intended).

item.title: A visual aid: when ‚Äúgay‚Äù is okay
item.description: For those of you still struggling with the idea of when it is and isn‚Äôt ideal to use the word ‚Äúgay‚Äù, even after reading my article outlining the whole idea, I decided to create a few visual aids. Hopefully they are straightforward.

item.title: 30+ Examples of Cisgender Privileges
item.description: Following is a list of cisgender identity privileges. If you are cisgender, listed below are benefits that result from your alignment of identity and perceived identity. If cisgender is a new term to you, here‚Äôs how I define it in my list of LGBTQ+ vocabulary:

item.title: Breaking through the binary: Gender explained using continuums
item.description: Gender is a tough subject to tackle. ¬†There are a lot of facets to consider, a lot of pressures at play, and we have all been conditioned in such a way that our first instinct is almost unanimously wrong. ¬†But we‚Äôre going to tackle it. ¬†No, we‚Äôre going to tackle the snot¬†out of it. ¬†Coming to our aid, I would like to present to you: The Genderbread Person!
